questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presented with generalized fatigue, frequent urination, and increased thirst over the past few months. He mentions that he has also been experiencing muscle weakness and occasional abdominal discomfort. His abdomen spine X-ray shows the below finding. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hyperparathyroidism

 

The presented clinical scenario and X-ray reveal widespread calcification in both kidneys, indicating a condition known as nephrocalcinosis, often associated with hyperparathyroidism.

 

Nephrocalcinosis is characterized by the accumulation of calcium in the kidney parenchyma or tubules, and it commonly arises from conditions that lead to elevated calcium levels, such as hyperparathyroidism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wilson's disease: This is a genetic disorder that causes copper accumulation in tissues, leading to neurological and hepatic symptoms. It does not typically present with nephrocalcinosis or the specific set of symptoms described, such as muscle weakness and abdominal discomfort related to calcium imbalance.

 

Option B. Addison's disease: This condition involves adrenal insufficiency and can present with fatigue and abdominal pain but is not associated with nephrocalcinosis. It also does not explain the hypercalcemia indicated by kidney calcifications in the X-ray.

 

Option C. Cystic fibrosis: Primarily affects the lungs and digestive system, leading to thick mucus secretions and digestive complications. It is not associated with kidney calcifications or the hormonal imbalances of the parathyroid gland as seen in hyperparathyroidism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Widespread kidney calcifications seen on X-ray, coupled with symptoms of fatigue, frequent urination, and increased thirst, are suggestive of hyperparathyroidism. This condition results from excessive secretion of parathyroid hormone, leading to elevated blood calcium levels and subsequent calcium deposition in organs like the kidneys (nephrocalcinosis).

questions.text: Identify the finding in the given ultrasound image. (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Phrygian cap

 

Phrygian caps are the most common congenital anatomic variant of the gallbladder. It denotes folding of the fundus back upon the gallbladder body and is asymptomatic with no pathological significance.

 

It is a normal anatomical variant.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mercedes-Benz sign: This sign is typically associated with pneumobilia, or air within the biliary tree, often seen in cases of fistula between the intestine and bile ducts or after certain surgical procedures. It is characterized by radiolucent branching structures that resemble the Mercedes-Benz logo, which is not evident in this ultrasound image.

 

Option B. Gall bladder polyp: Polyps would appear as echogenic masses attached to the gallbladder wall. They are usually well-defined and can vary in size. The image does not display any such formations.

 

Option C. Gall bladder cancer: This would generally appear as irregular, often thickened masses within the gallbladder, potentially with more heterogeneous echotexture compared to the surrounding liver tissue. This ultrasound does not show features typical of malignancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Phrygian cap is the most common congenital anatomic variant of the gallbladder, appearing as a fold at the gallbladder fundus. It is asymptomatic and has no pathological significance, important to recognize in imaging to differentiate it from potential abnormalities.

choices.text: Mode is affected by extreme values
Mean is affected by extreme values
Median is calculated by overall observations
Mode can be used as a qualitative data descriptor

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false for descriptors of central tendency? [INICET MAY 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Mode is affected by extreme values

 

  • Extreme values in a given dataset do not influence the mode.
  • Mode is the most frequent or most commonly occurring value in a distribution.
  • It is uninfluenced by extreme values and can be used to describe qualitative data

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mean is affected by extreme values: This is true. Extreme values (outliers) can significantly affect the mean, making it an unreliable measure of central tendency in skewed distributions.

 

Option C. Median is calculated by overall observations: This is true. The median is determined by arranging all observations in order and finding the middle value, or the average of the two middle values if the number of observations is even.

 

Option D. Mode can be used as a qualitative data descriptor: This is true. The mode is applicable to qualitative data as it represents the most frequently occurring category or value.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The mode is not affected by extreme values and can be used to describe qualitative data.
  • In contrast, the mean is affected by extreme values, and the median is a robust measure of central tendency that is calculated using overall observations.

choices.text: Dark ground microscopy

questions.text: A pregnant female visited the obstetrics and gynecology outpatient department (OBG OPD) for her regular prenatal examination. Her past pregnancy involved a stillbirth at 28 weeks. She has a history of engaging in sexual relations with multiple partners and recalls a painless sore on her vulva before her previous pregnancy. What initial investigative step should be taken for this patient? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) VDRL

 

The given scenario with a pregnant female has a history of stillbirth and painless genital ulcer is suggestive of Syphilis. So, Venereal disease research laboratory test (VDRL test) will be the first investigation to be done.

 

SYPHILIS IN PREGNANCY

 

  • Caused by Treponema pallidum
  • Primary Syphilis – Characterized by painless, nontender, single papule over the genitalia, that rapidly becomes eroded and usually becomes indurated, and is called a hard chancre.
  • Kassowitz Law – gradually improving fetal outcomes in congenital syphilis
  • Screening test – VDRL (done for all antenatal patients; May be false positive)
  • USG: FGR, hepatomegaly, fetal anemia, hydrops, placentomegaly
  • Treatment – Benzathine penicillin 2.4 million U

 

Other options:

 

Option A. HIV ELISA: HIV ELISA is done routinely for screening antenatal patients.

 

Option C. Dark ground microscopy: Dark ground microscopy is done when an active ulcer is present.

 

Option D. Culture: Treponema pallidum can’t be cultured. It is not the preferred method to diagnose or screen syphilis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a pregnant woman with a history of stillbirth and a painless genital ulcer, the initial investigation should be the VDRL test to screen for syphilis, as syphilis can significantly impact pregnancy outcomes and requires prompt treatment.

questions.text: Identify the image? (INCET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Subperiosteal abscess

 

The image shown is a cross-sectional CT scan of the head, particularly focusing on the orbit which is highlighting an abnormal finding adjacent to the orbit, which is indicative of a subperiosteal abscess.

 

Subperiosteal Abscess is forms between the orbit's periosteum (a dense layer of vascular connective tissue covering the bones) and the bone. It is usually a complication of sinusitis, especially ethmoid sinusitis, which can lead to infection spreading to the orbital area. On the CT scan, it appears as a localized bulge or collection adjacent to the bone, as shown in the image. This is consistent with the marking on the image indicating a crescent-shaped fluid collection that deforms the normal contour of the orbit.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Orbital Cellulitis: This condition involves inflammation and infection of the soft tissues of the orbit behind the orbital septum. However, orbital cellulitis typically involves more diffuse inflammation that would visibly impact more of the orbital tissue on imaging.

 

Option C. Preseptal Cellulitis: This infection involves the eyelid and skin anterior to the orbital septum, without affecting the orbit itself. The condition would not typically show significant findings behind the orbital septum on a CT scan, as seen in the image.

 

Option D. Sinusitis Only: While sinusitis, the inflammation of the sinus linings, can lead to complications such as a subperiosteal abscess, sinusitis itself would typically show thickened sinus linings and air-fluid levels within the sinus cavities on a CT scan, without necessarily involving the orbit unless complicated by adjacent infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Subperiosteal Abscess is crucial because it requires prompt treatment to prevent potential complications, including vision loss and intracranial spread of infection. Management typically involves antibiotics and may require surgical intervention to drain the abscess.

questions.text: A child presents with breathlessness. On chest X-ray, the following object is seen. Identify? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Button battery

 

Explanation:

 

The image you’ve provided shows a radiopaque object in the esophagus of a child, which is identified as a button battery.

 

On X-rays, button batteries typically present as small, circular objects with a double rim or halo effect. This is because they have a distinctive two-layer structure which shows up clearly on radiographs. The appearance in the X-ray  is characteristic of a button battery, with a clearly visible double rim. This is a medical emergency due to the risk of rapid and severe damage to the mucosal tissues from electrical discharge and leakage of caustic substances.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Coin: Coins are also circular and radiopaque on X-rays but lack the double rim feature seen with button batteries. Coins tend to be uniform in density throughout. Although they are a common type of foreign body ingested by children, they generally pose less immediate danger compared to button batteries.

 

Option C. Ball: A small ball, depending on its material, might appear on an X-ray if it's dense enough. However, it would not typically show the structured double rim characteristic of a button battery.

 

Option D. Bottle Cap: Bottle caps may appear circular but would show irregular edges or threading and do not have the double rim appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Immediate identification and removal of an ingested button battery are crucial due to the rapid damage that can occur. Emergency endoscopic retrieval is usually necessary to prevent severe injury or death.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with complaints of vertigo, sensorineural hearing loss and tinnitus which lasts minutes to hours with accompanied nausea and vomiting. On investigation, there is endolymphatic hypertension present. What is the diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Meniere’s disease

The patient's symptoms and the diagnostic finding of endolymphatic hypertension align with Meniere's disease. 

Characterized by episodes of vertigo, sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and aural fullness, lasting from minutes to hours. The symptoms are due to the accumulation of fluid in the inner ear (endolymphatic hydrops), leading to increased pressure within the endolymphatic system.

Other Options:

 Option B. Otosclerosis: A condition primarily affecting the bones of the middle ear, particularly the stapes. It causes conductive hearing loss, not typically associated with vertigo or tinnitus of the type seen in Meniere’s disease.

Option C. Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV): Characterized by brief episodes of vertigo related to changes in head position. It involves the dislodgment of otoliths within the inner ear, leading to brief, intense episodes of vertigo, without the auditory symptoms typical of Meniere's disease. 

Option D. Acoustic Neuroma (Vestibular Schwannoma): A benign tumor on the vestibular nerve, leading to progressive, unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and balance disturbances. It usually does not cause episodic vertigo like Meniere's disease.

Educational Objective:

Meniere’s disease is a chronic condition that requires management of symptoms through lifestyle changes, medications to control vertigo, and sometimes more invasive treatments to manage fluid pressure in the inner ear.

questions.text: Match the following muscles with their action at shoulder joint: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A-2, B-3, C-4, D-1

 

A. Latissimus dorsi: This muscle is known as the "stand at ease" muscle, the "climbers muscle," and the "swimmers muscle." It originates from the back and inserts into the front between two major muscles. When it contracts, it causes backward movement, extension, adduction, and medial rotation of the shoulder. Therefore, its action is extension with medial rotation (Action 2).

 

B. Supraspinatus: Located above the spine of the scapula, the supraspinatus muscle, when it contracts, moves the arm away from the midline, which is known as abduction. Hence, its action is abduction (Action 3).

 

C. Infraspinatus: This muscle originates from the back and rotates the arm outward when it contracts, causing lateral rotation. Thus, its action is lateral rotation (Action 4).

 

D. Pectoralis Major (sternal head): Originating from the midline (sternum and clavicle) and inserting into the lateral lip of the intertubercular sulcus, this muscle, when contracted, causes movement to the front (flexion). Therefore, its action is flexion (Action 1).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Latissimus dorsi is responsible for extension with medial rotation.
  • Supraspinatus is responsible for abduction.
  • Infraspinatus is responsible for lateral rotation.
  • Pectoralis Major (sternal head) is responsible for flexion.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male underwent NCCT abdomen for suspected renal calculi. An incidental finding was noted in the liver. What is the likely diagnosis? (INCET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hydatid cyst

 

Explanation:

 

The above CT image showing a calcified lesion in the liver with a lamellar wall which indicates hydatid disease.

 

Caused by Echinococcus granulosus → Humans – accidental host

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hepatocellular carcinoma: Typically presents as a solid tumor with irregular borders and might show vascular invasion or enhancement after contrast administration, not typically calcified.

 

Option B. Fibronodular hyperplasia: Refers to a benign liver lesion that generally does not demonstrate the clear, calcified, and layered appearance of a hydatid cyst.

 

Option C. Liver abscess: Would more likely present as a fluid-filled lesion with possible air-fluid levels and peripheral enhancement after contrast, not the lamellar calcification seen here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hydatid cysts in the liver are recognized on CT scans by their calcified, lamellar structure and are an important differential when considering cystic liver lesions, particularly in regions where Echinococcus is endemic.

questions.text: A patient presents to the casualty following blunt trauma to the chest. A chest X-ray was done. Among the following radiographs, in which case would you further evaluate the patient before putting a chest tube? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3,4

 

Explanation:

 

  1. Pneumothorax
  2. Hemothorax
  3. Consolidation
  4. Diaphragmatic hernia

 

Image 3: Consolidation would be managed symptomatically and chest tube shouldn’t be inserted.

 

Image 4: Diaphragmatic hernia: A direct blow to the diaphragm can cause it to rupture, allowing abdominal contents to herniate into the chest. In the case of stomach herniation into the chest, a nasogastric tube followed by chest radiography can be helpful. Video-assisted thoracoscopy or laparoscopy is the most accurate investigation.

 

Other Options:

 

Radiographs 1-2 show hemothorax and pneumothorax. Intercostal chest drains should be inserted into the fifth intercostal space. The safe landmark is a triangle anterior to the midaxillary line above the nipple, below, and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of blunt chest trauma, careful evaluation of chest radiographs is crucial. Consolidations (Image 3) and diaphragmatic hernias (Image 4) require specific management strategies distinct from those of pneumothorax or hemothorax, where immediate chest tube placement is standard.

questions.text: The rupture of penile urethra does not cause extravasation of blood into which of the following spaces? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Deep perineal pouch

 

Option B. Deep perineal pouch: This is a space situated superior to the perineal membrane and inferior to the pelvic diaphragm. It contains the membranous urethra, deep transverse perineal muscles, and parts of the external urethral sphincter. Extravasation of urine is possible in deep perineal pouch.

 

When there is a rupture of the penile urethra (often due to trauma, such as a straddle injury), the extravasation of urine and blood can occur into various anatomical spaces, depending on the location and nature of the injury.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superficial perineal pouch: This is a space located in the urogenital triangle of the perineum, bounded above by the perineal membrane and below by the perineal (Colles') fascia. The pouch contains the root of the penis (including the bulb of the penis) and the associated muscles. A rupture of the penile urethra can cause extravasation of urine and blood into this space.

 

Option C. Skin around penis. The skin around base of penis may get involved if the rupture is located in the bulbous part of urethra.

 

Option D. Skin around the scrotum: With a rupture of the penile urethra, especially if the rupture occurs in the bulbous part located within the superficial perineal pouch, the extravasated urine and blood can dissect through the fascial layers and present as swelling and bruising around the scrotum and base of the penis. This is often referred to as a "butterfly" pattern of bruising, as the extravasated fluid can spread anteriorly onto the anterior abdominal wall and laterally to the thighs but is typically limited superiorly by Scarpa's fascia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rupture of the penile urethra causes extravasation of blood into the superficial perineal pouch, scrotum, penis, and then up to the lower anterior abdominal wall.

 

The membranous layer of superficial fascia attaches to the ischiopubic rami and forms the lateral borders of the urogenital triangle. Thus, the urine does not extravasate to the thigh.

questions.text: All of the following parameters are true for anemia of chronic disease except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Decrease in serum ferritin

 

Anemia of chronic disease (ACD), also known as anemia of inflammation, is a common type of anemia that occurs in the context of chronic infections (like TB, chronic osteomyelitis), autoimmune diseases (RA,IBD), cancer, and other chronic conditions. It is characterized by several key features related to iron metabolism and the body's response to inflammation.

 

This statement is incorrect. Serum ferritin is an acute-phase reactant, meaning its levels increase in response to inflammation. Therefore, in ACD, serum ferritin levels are typically increased or normal, not decreased. Ferritin acts as a marker of iron stores, and in ACD, iron stores are usually normal or increased, but the iron is not readily available for use.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase in serum hepcidin: Hepcidin is a peptide hormone produced by the liver that regulates iron homeostasis. In ACD, hepcidin levels are increased due to inflammation. Hepcidin inhibits iron absorption from the gut and the release of iron from macrophages, leading to reduced availability of iron for erythropoiesis.

 

Option C. Associated with conditions like TB: ACD is often associated with chronic infections and inflammatory diseases. The chronic inflammation leads to the production of cytokines like IL-6, which increase hepcidin production and subsequently cause the anemia.

 

Option D. Normal iron stores: Iron stores in ACD are usually normal or increased. The issue in ACD is not the lack of iron but rather the body's inability to utilize the iron effectively due to the inflammatory response.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serum ferritin levels increase in anemia of chronic disease.

 

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1234

questions.text: Match the following: (INCET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-d, 2-b, 3-a, 4-c

 

Explanation:

 

1. Football sign: This sign is associated with pneumoperitoneum, where an accumulation of gas in the peritoneal cavity gives a silhouette resembling a football on X-ray images.

 

 

2. Rat tail sign: Typically seen in carcinoma of the esophagus, this sign describes the tapering of the esophageal lumen due to the tumor, resembling a rat’s tail..

 

 

3. String sign: Found in CHPS (Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis), it refers to the appearance of a narrowed, elongated channel through the pylorus.

 

 

4. Inverted umbrella sign: This is seen in cases of TB (tuberculosis), particularly referring to the appearance of a contracted cecum and narrow ileocecal junction

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Whole- body CT scan protocol for a trauma patient includes all, except? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CT limbs

 

Explanation:

 

CT Limbs is not included in the whole-body CT of a trauma patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CT Head: Non-contrast CT (NCCT) of the head to check for any intracranial hemorrhages or fractures.

 

Option B. CT Cervical Spine: NCCT of the cervical spine to assess for any fractures or dislocations that may compromise the spinal cord.

 

Option D. CT Abdomen: Contrast-enhanced CT of the torso, including the abdomen and pelvis, to evaluate for internal injuries such as organ lacerations, bleeding, or other trauma-related abnormalities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Whole-body CT or trauma CT includes:

 

  1. NCCT head
  2. NCCT C-spine
  3. Contrast-enhanced CT of torso

questions.text: A 45-year-old banker presented with vague abdominal pain. On USG, he was found to have a renal mass lesion. CECT was done, as shown below. What is the diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Renal angiomyolipoma

 

Explanation:

 

The CT image presented here shows well-circumscribed lesions with low attenuation (black in color) that indicate fatty tissue. The presence of macroscopic fat is strongly suggestive angiomyolipoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. RCC (Renal Cell Carcinoma): Typically appears as a solid renal mass that may enhance heterogeneously after contrast administration and generally does not contain macroscopic fat.

 

Option B. Renal oncocytoma: A benign renal tumor that typically appears as a well-circumscribed, homogeneously enhancing mass on imaging, without the characteristic fat component seen in angiomyolipomas.

 

Option D. Renal cyst: Would appear as a fluid-filled, round structure with no enhancement; the lesion in the image is solid with fatty components, inconsistent with a simple cyst.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The clinical finding in the 10-year-old boy includes fever, joint pain, and a hand lesion as shown in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis based on these findings? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gottron's papules - Juvenile dermatomyositis.

 

  • Juvenile dermatomyositis is a rare inflammatory disease affecting the skin and muscles. It typically presents in children with a characteristic skin rash and muscle weakness.
  • Gottron's papules are distinctive red or violet, raised, scaly lesions seen over knuckles (dorsal interphalangeal or metacarpophalangeal joints), elbows, knees, and other extensor surfaces, highly suggestive of dermatomyositis.
  • The combination of fever, joint pain, and Gottron's papules strongly indicates juvenile dermatomyositis.

 

Other features associated with Dermatomyositis are:

 

  • The Gottron's sign is a distribution of symmetric, non-scaling, violaceous, erythematous macules or plaques that are frequently atrophic.

 

 

Gottron's sign: seen in the above image

 

  • Shawl sign or V-sign: Fixed macular erythema spanning the shoulders and outer arms (Shawl distribution) as seen in the image below

 

 

  • Periungual telangiectasias: enlarged capillaries in the nail folds.

 

 

  • Mechanic's hand: Roughening and cracking of the fingertip and side skin that results in scuffed, crooked lines that resemble those of a mechanic or manual laborer.

 

 

  • Proximal myopathy: Patients have trouble performing everyday activities like climbing stairs, getting up, and lifting their arms above their heads.

 

Laboratory evaluation of patients with dermatomyositis will reveal elevated serum creatinine kinase and antinuclear antibodies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rheumatoid nodules - Juvenile rheumatoid arthritis:

 

  • Juvenile rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune disorder causing chronic joint inflammation in children.
  • Rheumatoid nodules are firm, painless, subcutaneous nodules that usually occur in areas of pressure but are not typically seen in the hands in this form.
  • The lesion in the image doesn't match the typical appearance of rheumatoid nodules.

 

Option C Sclerodactyly - Systemic sclerosis:

 

  • Systemic sclerosis is a connective tissue disease characterized by skin thickening and hardening (scleroderma).
  • Sclerodactyly refers to thickening and tightening of the skin on the fingers and hands, leading to a claw-like appearance.
  • The lesion shown doesn't indicate the skin thickening or tightness characteristic of sclerodactyly.

 

Option D Mechanic's hand - Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE):

 

  • SLE is an autoimmune disease affecting multiple organ systems.
  • Mechanic's hand is a sign associated more with dermatomyositis than SLE, characterized by rough, cracked skin on the sides of the fingers, mimicking the hands of a manual labourer.
  • The presentation of mechanic's hand in SLE is less common and the symptoms described do not align well with SLE.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a case involving fever, joint pain, and hand lesions in a child, the presence of Gottron's papules is indicative of Juvenile dermatomyositis.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 53 page no 53.1-53.12

Harrison’s principles of internal medicine 21st edition Page 2820-2821

questions.text: Patient had difficulty in walking upstairs. When he was made to bear weight on right lower limb, the left-sided pelvis dropped down, but when he was standing on the left lower limb, the right-sided pelvis moved up. Which of the following is the likely lesion? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Right superior gluteal nerve palsy

 

WADDLING (GLUTEAL OR TRENDELENBURG) GAIT

 

  • This gait is characteristic of the gluteal muscle weakness that is seen in the progressive muscular dystrophies, but it occurs as well in chronic forms of spinal muscular atrophy, in certain inflammatory myopathies, lumbosacral nerve root compression, and with congenital dislocation of the hips.
  • It can also occur in neurogenic conditions in which the superior gluteal nerve is involved.
  • In normal walking, as weight is placed alternately on each leg, the hip is fixated by the gluteal muscles, particularly the gluteus medius, allowing for a slight rise of the opposite hip and tilt of the trunk to the weight-bearing side.
  • With weakness of the glutei, however, there is a failure to stabilize the weight-bearing hip, causing it to bulge outward and the opposite side of the pelvis to drop, with inclination of the trunk to that side.
  • The alternation in lateral trunk movements results in the roll or waddle.
  • With unilateral gluteal weakness, often the result of damage to the first sacral nerve root, tilting and dropping of the pelvis (“pelvic ptosis”) is apparent on only one side as the patient overlifts the leg when walking.
  • In several of the muscular dystrophies, an accentuation of lumbar lordosis is often seen.
  • Also, childhood cases may be complicated by muscular contractures, leading to an equinovarus position of the foot, so that the waddle is combined with walking on the toes (“toe walking”).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Left superior gluteal nerve palsy. When the patient is standing on one leg, the opposite pelvis should be lifted upwards by abduction of the ipsilateral hip joint, in a normal patient. When the abductors are weak due to superior gluteal nerve paresis, the pelvis will sag, called positive Trendelenburg sign. In a patient with a positive Trendelenburg sign, the pelvis sags toward the normal unsupported side, which is the swing leg. When the left superior gluteal nerve is affected, on standing on the left lower limb, the right side pelvis will drop and when the patient stands on the right leg, the left side pelvis will be lifted up.

 

Option C. Right inferior gluteal nerve palsy. The inferior gluteal nerve supplies the gluteus maximus muscle. It is therefore, responsible for extending the trunk from a forward bending position and extending the hip from sitting-to-standing or during stair-climbing or rising from a squatted position. The nerve does not confer any sensation. Injury to this nerve is most commonly iatrogenic in origin and is the most at risk nerve during total hip arthroplasty via a posterior approach. Injury typically leads to an altered gait pattern known as gluteus maximus ‘lurch’. The sequelae of nerve injury are denervation of the ipsilateral gluteus maximus muscle. The lurching gait results from the weakening or absence of an ipsilateral hip extension. Clinically, patients may also report wasting of the ipsilateral gluteus maximus muscle and loss of the defined shape to the affected buttock. In a normal gait cycle, the gluteus maximus begin to contract at the moment of the ipsilateral heel-strike to initiate ipsilateral hip extension. In inferior gluteal nerve injury, the trunk will extend when the heel strikes on the ground on the affected side to compensate for weak/absent hip extension. This backward trunk lurch is present in the whole stance phase of the gait cycle and locks the hip in extension. In some cases, the hamstrings muscle compensates to an extent. Therefore, in the right inferior gluteal nerve palsy, the right side hip will not extend during the initial heel strike and the trunk will lean backwards/extend.

 

Option D. Left inferior gluteal nerve palsy. In the injury of left sided gluteal nerve, the left hip will not extend during the initial heel strike, leading to backward lurch or extension of the trunk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • On standing on the right lower limb, the left side pelvis drops and while standing on the left leg, the right side pelvis lifted up. This is indicative of right superior gluteal nerve palsy. This sign is called Trendelenburg Sign.

questions.text: What type of MRI image is given below? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B Susceptibility weighted image

 

Explanation:

 

Susceptibility weighted imaging (SWI) is an MRI sequence which is sensitive to compounds that can distort the local magnetic field.

 

Type of Gradient echo sequence / T2* sequence 

 

Black dots s/o hemorrhage known as blooming

 

Sequence of choice for DAI (diffuse axonal injury)   

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Proton density image: Typically used to provide good anatomical detail and contrast of soft tissues, not specifically sensitive to magnetic susceptibilities.

 

Option C. Gradient echo image: While SWI uses gradient echo sequences, it specifically exploits phase data and magnitude data to enhance the visibility of substances affecting magnetic susceptibility.

 

Option D. Inversion recovery image: This MRI technique is used to suppress or enhance certain tissue types based on their relaxation properties, which is not indicative of the contrast seen in this image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Susceptibility weighted imaging (SWI) is particularly useful in detecting and differentiating substances in the brain that affect magnetic susceptibility, such as iron and blood, making it an excellent choice for identifying microhemorrhages and assessing diffuse axonal injury.

questions.text: Positive charge in thick ascending loop of Henle is maintained by recirculation of which cation: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) K+

 

In the thick ascending loop of Henle, the maintenance of positive charge is primarily achieved through the recirculation of potassium ions (K+).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. H+ (Hydrogen ions): Hydrogen ions play a role in regulating the pH of urine but are not primarily responsible for maintaining positive charge in the thick ascending loop of Henle.

 

Option B. Na+ (Sodium ions): Sodium ions are actively reabsorbed in the thick ascending loop of Henle but are not the primary cation responsible for maintaining positive charge in this segment.

 

Option C. NH4+ (Ammonium ions): Ammonium ions are involved in acid-base regulation in the kidneys but are not the primary cation responsible for maintaining positive charge in the thick ascending loop of Henle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The thick ascending loop of Henle (TAL) is impermeable to water but there is active reabsorption of Na, Cl and K. The cotransporter in membrane of TAL is responsible for reabsorption of 1/3 of both Na and Cl in the body. On the basolateral side there is Na/K ATPase pump which throws sodium out and K in. This K+ is transported back into lumen through Renal outer medullary K+ channel (ROMK) channel for it to be recirculated.

 

 

Ref- https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4220766/

choices.text: Toxoplasma gondii

questions.text: Identify the organism from the lifecycle shown in the image given below? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Toxoplasma gondii

 

The given image shows the lifecycle of Toxoplasma gondii.

 

Toxoplasma gondii is an obligate intracellular parasite that causes toxoplasmosis.

 

Definitive hosts - Members of Felidae (domestic cats and their relatives). The enteric cycle occurs in definitive hosts.

 

Intermediate hosts in nature (including birds and rodents). Exoenteric cycle occurs in intermediate hosts such as humans, mice, rats, etc.

 

Life cycle of toxoplasma gondii

 

  1. Unsporulated oocysts are shed in the cat’s feces. Although oocysts are usually only shed for 1–3 weeks, large numbers may be shed.
  2. Oocysts take 1–5 days to sporulate in the environment and become infective. Intermediate hosts in nature (including birds and rodents) become infected after ingesting soil, water or plant material contaminated with oocysts.
  3. Oocysts transform into tachyzoites shortly after ingestion. These tachyzoites localize in neural and muscle tissue and develop into tissue cyst bradyzoites.
  4. Cats become infected after consuming intermediate hosts harboring tissue cysts. Cats may also become infected directly by ingestion of sporulated oocysts.
  5. Animals bred for human consumption and wild game may also become infected with tissue cysts after ingestion of sporulated oocysts in the environment.

 

Humans can become infected by any of several routes:

 

  • Eating undercooked meat of animals harboring tissue cysts
  • Consuming food or water contaminated with cat feces or by contaminated environmental samples (such as fecal-contaminated soil or changing the litter box of a pet cat).
  • Blood transfusion or organ transplantation.
  • Transplacentally from mother to fetus.
  • In the human host, the parasites form tissue cysts, most commonly in skeletal muscle, myocardium, brain, and eyes; these cysts may remain throughout the life of the host.

 

 

Diagnosis is usually achieved by serology, although tissue cysts may be observed in stained biopsy specimens.

 

Diagnosis of congenital infections can be achieved by detecting T. gondii DNA in amniotic fluid using molecular methods such as PCR

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Cystoisospora: Causes isosporiasis, primarily affecting the gastrointestinal tract. Its lifecycle involves humans as the definitive host.

 

Option B. Cryptosporidium: Causes cryptosporidiosis, an intestinal illness. The lifecycle involves direct fecal-oral transmission.

 

Option C. Plasmodium knowlesi: Causes malaria, with a lifecycle involving mosquitoes as vectors and humans as host.

 

Educational Objective

 

Toxoplasma gondii is an obligate intracellular parasite with a complex lifecycle involving cats as definitive hosts and various animals, including humans, as intermediate hosts. The lifecycle stages, including oocysts and tissue cysts, are crucial for transmission and infection.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presented with mild intermittent upper abdominal pain. X-ray is given below. What is the diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hiatal hernia

 

Explanation:

 

Retrocardiac air fluid level is seen on CXR which is suggestive of a hiatal hernia. It is defined as the displacement through esophageal hiatus of GE junction or other parts of the stomach into the thoracic cavity

 

 

IOC for hiatal hernia: Contrast enhanced CT + oral contrast (Iohexol most commonly) (to determine obstruction/ Volvulus)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bochdalek hernia: This is a congenital diaphragmatic hernia typically occurring at the posterolateral part of the diaphragm, not associated with the retrocardiac region.

 

Option B. Morgagni hernia: Another type of congenital diaphragmatic hernia that occurs anteriorly at the sternocostal triangles, not retrocardiac.

 

Option D. Eventration of diaphragm: Involves an abnormal elevation of the diaphragm muscle, not typically presenting as an air-fluid level in the retrocardiac area.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hiatal hernia can be diagnosed on plain chest X-ray when an air-fluid level is visible in the retrocardiac area, indicating herniation of stomach contents into the thorax through the esophageal hiatus. Contrast-enhanced CT with oral contrast is the imaging of choice for further evaluation, particularly to assess for any complications like obstruction or volvulus.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presented with confusion, constipation, and persistent low mood. ALP was elevated. She was diagnosed with primary hyperparathyroidism. Which of the following is the imaging of choice? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sestamibi scan

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical features of 40-year-old woman with confusion, constipation, along with persistent low mood is suggestive of hypercalcemia, which could be due to primary Hyperparathyroidism.

 

IOC for parathyroid adenoma: Tc99-Sestamibi scan

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MRI: While MRI can provide detailed soft tissue images, it is not the preferred imaging modality for detecting parathyroid adenomas.

 

Option B. FDG PET: PET scans are used in cancer imaging and are not specific for identifying parathyroid adenomas.

 

Option C. CT: While CT scans can identify anatomical details and some tumors, they lack the specificity of Sestamibi scans in identifying hyperactive parathyroid tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A Sestamibi scan is specifically useful for identifying parathyroid adenomas in patients suspected of having primary hyperparathyroidism, due to its ability to effectively localize hyperfunctioning parathyroid tissue.

questions.text: Which of the following jugular venous pressure (JVP) waves corresponds to the isovolumetric contraction phase of the cardiac cycle? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) c wave

 

The jugular venous pressure (JVP) waveform consists of multiple waves that correspond to different phases of the cardiac cycle.

 

The "c" wave corresponds to the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during ventricular contraction, causing a brief increase in pressure in the right atrium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The "a" wave corresponds to the atrial contraction, which occurs during the late ventricular filling phase of the cardiac cycle. This is the period before the closure of the mitral/ tricuspid valve. The "a" wave is caused by the contraction of the atrium, leading to a brief increase in right atrial pressure.

 

Option C. The "x" descent corresponds to the returning of the tricuspid valve to its normal position during ventricular contraction (i.e. ejection) and atrial relaxation.

 

Option D. The "y" descent corresponds to the rapid emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle during ventricular diastole.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "c" wave of the jugular venous pressure waveform corresponds to the isovolumetric contraction phase of the cardiac cycle, reflecting the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium as the right ventricle begins to contract.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents to the emergency department with intermittent episodes of severe colicky abdominal pain, vomiting, and passage of currant jelly stools. The clinical suspicion is towards intussusception. Taking the child's immunization history, which recent vaccine could be associated with a slightly increased risk of this condition? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Rotavirus vaccine

 

Rotavirus vaccine is associated with a complication of intussusception.

 

ROTA virus vaccines

 

  • 4 Types – but 2 used in NIS
  • ROTAVAC and ROTASIL (live, att., lyophilized with diluent citrate bicarbonate buffer)
  • ROTAVAC →1 dose = 0.5 ml
  • ROTASIIL → 1 dose – 2.5 ml with 6 ml syringe
  • 3 doses – 6, 10, 14 weeks
  • Complication - INTUSSUSCEPTION

 

 

 

Other 3 Options: Not associated with intussusception.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rotavirus vaccine is associated with a rare complication of intussusception, an important consideration when assessing an infant presenting with symptoms of this condition.

choices.text: No treatment required as he already has Hep B antibody titres from vaccination

questions.text: A resident had a needle stick injury while dealing with a Hepatitis B positive patient. Serology was done and HBsAg was negative and the Anti-HBs was >105 mIU/ml. What is the next step of management? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) No treatment required as he already has Hep B antibody titres from vaccination

 

No treatment required as he already has Hep B antibody titres from vaccination: The resident's serology shows that HBsAg is negative and Anti-HBs is greater than 105 mIU/ml, which indicates that he has sufficient immunity against Hepatitis B from prior vaccination. No further treatment is necessary because the antibody titres are already protective.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Booster dose of vaccine: Not required since the resident already has sufficient antibody levels indicating immunity.

 

Option B. Immunoglobulin with full vaccination: This would be necessary if the resident had low or no detectable antibody titres, indicating no prior immunity.

 

Option C. Repeat full course of vaccine: Not necessary because the resident already has adequate antibody titres indicating immunity.

 

Educational Objective

choices.text: Dilated loops of intestine with valvulae conniventes

questions.text: Which of the following is a finding of large bowel obstruction? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Dilated loops with haustrations

 

Explanation:

 

Dilated bowel loops with haustrations is a feature of large bowel obstruction.

Large bowel obstructions have colonic distension proximal to the obstruction with the distal portion collapsed. The colon is considered dilated if it is more than 6 cm in diameter while the cut off for caecum is 9cm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dilated loops of intestine with valvulae conniventes: Dilated loops of the intestine with plica circulars (valvulae conniventes) and predominantly central loops are features of the small bowel obstruction. The small bowel is considered dilated if it is more than 3 cm in diameter.

 

Option B. String of pearls sign: The string of pearls sign is also a feature of small bowel obstruction seen in plain radiographs or CT. It represents a row of gas bubbles trapped between the valvulae conniventes.

 

Option C. Central dilated bowel loops: While central dilation can occur in any intestinal obstruction, it is more typical of small bowel obstruction where the loops tend to centrally accumulate.

 

Educational Objective:


Identifying dilated loops with haustrations is critical for diagnosing large bowel obstruction, helping differentiate it from small bowel obstruction, which features dilated loops with valvulae conniventes and may show the string of pearls sign.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male with Marfanoid habitus presents with sharp chest pain and sudden onset dyspnea. Chest X-ray was performed and is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C Pneumothorax

 

Explanation:

 

The given CXR shows the presence of pneumothorax, which represents air in the pleural space. 

 

DIAGNOSIS: Right pneumothorax

 

MEDIASTINAL SHIFT: Contralateral

 

MOST SENSITIVE IX: CT scan

 

MOST SENSITIVE X-RAY: Expiratory X ray

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulmonary embolism: Often presents with sudden onset dyspnea and may show signs of right heart strain on imaging, but it does not directly cause the visible signs of air in the pleural cavity as seen in pneumothorax.

 

Option B. Hydropneumothorax: This would be indicated by both air and fluid levels within the pleural space, which are not visible in this X-ray.

 

Option D. Aortic dissection: Would potentially show mediastinal widening or other structural abnormalities, which are not depicted in this image.

 

Educational Objective:


Pneumothorax is identified by the visible presence of air in the pleural space, leading to lung collapse, and is commonly associated with sudden onset chest pain and dyspnea, especially in patients with connective tissue disorders like Marfan syndrome.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male was brought to the emergency room following a road traffic accident. On examination, his GCS was E2M2V3. He had no fractures and no hydrocephalus or raised intracranial pressure. Non-contrast CT was performed and was found to be normal. The likely diagnosis is? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A Diffuse axonal injury

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical scenario of the patient who had an RTA presents with an abnormal clinical manifestation and no imaging abnormality suggests diffuse axonal injury.

 

C/F: High energy trauma (road traffic accident) + Low GCS score / comatose

Initial investigation for DAI→ NCCT: Normal or tiny microbleeds

IOC for DAI → MRI

Sequence of MRI best: SWI/ Gradient MR: Shows blooming suggestive of axonal shearing

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Post-concussion syndrome: Patients with post-concussion syndrome have mild traumatic brain injury. It does not present with a severe clinical status as seen in this patient.

 

Option C. Extra Dural hemorrhage: Extradural hemorrhage results secondary to trauma to head. The bleeding is usually arterial and blood collects between outer dura and inner table of the skull. It can very well be visualized on CT.

 

Option D. Post-concussion syndrome: A cerebral herniation is a shift of cerebral tissue in an adjacent space. Intracranial brain herniation can be classified into 3 types - subfalcine, trans tentorial and tonsillar. A distinct clinical picture can be produced as a result of compression of neurovascular structures by the herniating part. CT is the imaging modality of choice because it can be done rapidly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of road traffic accidents where a patient presents with a significant neurological deficit and a normal initial CT scan, diffuse axonal injury should be considered. An MRI with specific sequences is required to confirm the diagnosis and understand the extent of injury.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female came to the OPD with complaints of backache. On examination, her eyes and pinna revealed blackish discoloration. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Alkaptonuria

 

Explanation:

 

Intervertebral disc calcification is seen in the image suggestive of alkaptonuria.

 

Deficiency: Homogentisic oxidase

 

Hyperpigmentation of ears and eyes suggestive of ochronosis is a clue. It is seen due to excessive build-up of homogentisic acid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DISH (Diffuse Idiopathic Skeletal Hyperostosis): Features ossification along the anterolateral aspect of at least four contiguous vertebral bodies, often with a "candle wax dripping" appearance, distinct from the findings in alkaptonuria.

 

Option B. Fluorosis: Typically presents with increased bone density and ossification of interosseous ligaments, not specifically associated with hyperpigmentation or the disc calcifications shown.

 

Option D. Ankylosing Spondylitis: Characterized by a "bamboo spine" appearance due to bony fusion, seen in younger patients (less than 50 years old), which does not typically include hyperpigmentation or the type of disc calcification seen in alkaptonuria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Alkaptonuria - Is characterized by a deficiency of the enzyme homogentisic oxidase
  • Fluorosis – Increased bone density with interosseous ligament ossification 
  • DISH VS   Ankylosing spondylitis

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presented with complaints of bone pain and abdominal cramps with persistent low mood. Which of the following would be the best investigation for a definitive diagnosis? (AIIMS 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Sestamibi scan

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical features of 40-year-old woman with bone pain and abdominal cramps along with persistent low mood is suggestive of hypercalcemia, which could be due to primary Hyperparathyroidism.

 

IOC for parathyroid adenoma: Tc99-Sestamibi scan

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging): While useful for detailed soft tissue imaging, MRI is not the first choice for detecting parathyroid adenomas.

 

Option C. Ultrasonogram: Can be used to locate parathyroid adenomas but has limitations in sensitivity and specificity compared to the Sestamibi scan.

 

Option D. CT scan (Computed Tomography): Provides good anatomic detail but is less specific than the Sestamibi scan for parathyroid adenomas and is not the primary diagnostic tool for suspected hyperparathyroidism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a definitive diagnosis in patients presenting with symptoms indicative of hypercalcemia and suspected primary hyperparathyroidism, a Sestamibi scan is the investigation of choice due to its specificity and ability to perform detailed scintigraphic imaging.

questions.text: Nucleus pulposus is derived from? (AIIMS 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Mark b

 

Explanation:

 

  • The notochord is a rod-like structure that forms during embryonic development and serves as the foundation for the future vertebral column.
  • The nucleus pulposus, the central gel-like core of the intervertebral disc, is derived from the notochord. The notochord initially provides structural support to the developing embryo and later contributes to the formation of the intervertebral discs.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mark d. Ectoderm:

 

  • The ectoderm is another primary germ layer of the developing embryo and gives rise to structures such as the nervous system, skin, and epidermal tissues.
  • The ectoderm does not contribute to the formation of the nucleus pulposus.

 

Option C. Mark a. Intraembryonic Mesoderm:

 

  • The intraembryonic mesoderm is a layer of embryonic tissue that gives rise to various structures in the developing embryo, including muscles, bones, and connective tissues.
  • While mesoderm does play a role in the development of the vertebral column and its associated structures, the nucleus pulposus specifically derives from the notochord.

 

Option D. Mark c. Endoderm:

 

  • The endoderm is one of the three primary germ layers of the developing embryo and gives rise to the epithelial linings of various organs, including the gastrointestinal tract, respiratory tract, and other internal organs.
  • The endoderm is not directly involved in the formation of the nucleus pulposus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gastrulation (Embryonic development of the germ layers):

 

  • Gastrulation is the early embryological process by which an embryo changes from a one-dimensional layer of epithelial cells (blastula) to a multilayered structure known as a gastrula.
  • The notochord is a rod-like embryological structure that is derived during gastrulation and plays an important role in vertebrate development.
  • The nucleus pulposus is the gelatinous centre of the intervertebral disc formed by the expansion of the notochord (by its remnants). As a result, it is derived from the notochord.

choices.text: The patient should not be shifted and portable X-ray machine should be used after neck Stabilization
The doctor will instruct the radiographer to take cervical and chest X ray
The doctor will instruct the radiographer to take cervical X ray AP and lateral view without any cervical support
The doctor should order a cervical X ray and shift the patient from the trolley by himself

questions.text: A victim of a road traffic accident presented with paralysis of both his upper and lower limbs. He has not passed urine and tenderness is elicited in the cervical region. What will be your advice? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The patient should not be shifted and portable X-ray machine should be used after neck stabilization

 

The given clinical situation is suggestive of a cervical spine injury due to trauma. The patient should not be shifted and a portable X-ray machine should be used after neck stabilization.

 

This option is correct because the patient is experiencing paralysis of both upper and lower limbs, which is indicative of a potential cervical spine injury. In such cases, it is crucial not to move the patient until the cervical spine is stabilized to prevent any further damage. Using a portable X-ray machine can help assess the cervical spine without the need to move the patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. The doctor will instruct the radiographer to take cervical and chest X-rays: The patient's cervical spine must be stabilized before any radiographic evaluation is performed.

 

Option C. The doctor will instruct the radiographer to take cervical X-ray AP and lateral views without any cervical support: This option is not advisable because taking X-rays without cervical support can potentially worsen the patient's condition if there is a cervical spine injury. The patient's neck should be stabilized before any imaging is done.

 

Option D. The doctor should order a cervical X-ray and shift the patient from the trolley by himself: This option is not recommended because moving the patient without proper cervical spine stabilization can lead to further injury. The priority should be to immobilize the cervical spine and use imaging techniques that do not require moving the patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Management in a trauma patient with suspected cervical fracture consists of:

 

  1. The immediate step in the management of blunt/penetrating cervical trauma cases is spinal immobilization with a rigid cervical collar and a long spine board
  2. It is followed by eliciting extremity movement to grossly assess spinal cord function. Tenderness over the injured vertebrae or the presence of a deformity is indicated an associated fracture.

 

Imaging is done by X-ray or CT with portable X-ray machines being preferred to avoid further injury while mobilizing the patient. They are useful in visualizing thoracic and lumbar vertebrae but they cannot be used to visualize the cervicothoracic junction.

questions.text: A middle-aged female patient with a history of cholelithiasis, presented with vomiting and abdominal pain. The abdominal radiograph showed Rigler's triad. Which of these is not a component of Rigler's triad? (AIIMS 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Large bowel obstruction

 

Rigler's triad is a radiologic finding associated with gallstone ileus, consisting of three specific signs: pneumobilia (air within the biliary tree), small bowel obstruction, and an ectopic calcified gallstone, typically found in the right iliac fossa. These findings are indicative of a gallstone that has passed into the intestinal tract via a biliary-enteric fistula and is causing an obstruction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumobilia: Correctly identified as a part of Rigler's triad, indicating the presence of air within the biliary system due to a fistula between the biliary tree and the gastrointestinal tract.

 

Option B. Small Bowel Obstruction: Also a component of Rigler's triad, typically caused by the ectopic gallstone blocking the small intestine.

 

Option C. Ectopic Gall Stone: Another correct component of Rigler's triad, representing the gallstone that has migrated and is causing obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rigler triad consists of three findings seen in gallstone ileus:

 

  • Pneumobilia
  • Small Bowel Obstruction
  • Ectopic calcified gallstone, usually in the right iliac fossa

choices.text: Reassure and to check whether passed in stools

questions.text: A child presents with history of acute dysphagia. CXR is shown below. What is the next best step? (AIIMS 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Remove endoscopically

 

Explanation:

 

The given CXR shows a foreign body in the esophagus which is likely to be a button battery as seen by the double margins.

 

 

In profile/ en face: Foreign body is in the esophagus

 

The next step should be to endoscopically removing those batteries as they lead to tissue necrosis by liquefactive necrosis.

 

Patient’s oral intake should be prohibited until the location of the foreign body is confirmed. Never induce vomiting in these patients as it can again lodge back in the esophagus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Remove with bronchoscopy: Bronchoscopy is not suitable as the foreign body is located in the esophagus, not the airways.

 

Option C. Reassure and check whether passed in stools: This approach is inappropriate due to the urgent risk of tissue damage from the battery; immediate removal is necessary.

 

Option D. Induce vomiting: Inducing vomiting is contraindicated as it can cause further esophageal injury or lead to re-lodgement of the battery in the esophagus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of suspected ingestion of button batteries as seen on CXR, urgent endoscopic removal is critical to prevent tissue damage and potential complications. Vomiting should never be induced in these situations as it can exacerbate the problem.

choices.text: Most of the grafts are multi-visceral grafts.
It is not widely used due to vigorous rejection reactions.
The most dangerous complication is sepsis.
The most common indication is the ischemia

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement about intestinal transplantation: (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Most of the grafts are multi-visceral grafts

 

This statement is incorrect. While multi-visceral transplantation, which includes the intestine along with other abdominal organs like the liver and pancreas, can occur, it is not the most common type of intestinal transplantation. Isolated intestinal transplantation, where only the intestine is transplanted, is more common.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It is not widely used due to vigorous rejection reactions: This statement is correct. Intestinal transplantation is not as widely performed as other organ transplants like kidney or liver transplantation because the intestine is known to trigger vigorous rejection reactions.

 

Option C. The most dangerous complication is sepsis: This statement is correct. Sepsis is indeed a significant and life-threatening complication associated with intestinal transplantation. The immunosuppressive medications used to prevent rejection can increase the risk of infections, including sepsis.

 

Option D. The most common indication is ischemia. (Correct): Ischemia is one of the common indications for intestinal transplantation. It is often used when patients have suffered from ischemic bowel disease and other treatments have been ineffective.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multi-visceral grafts are rarely used in intestinal transplantation. The most common intestinal graft is small bowel graft, with or without the colon or a combined liver and small bowel graft.

 

All the other statements are correct.

 

Small bowel transplantation is the final treatment option when the outcome of reconstruction and lengthening procedures are unsatisfactory.

 

The small bowel transplant is highly immunogenic as it contains a large amount of gut-associated lymphoid tissue, donor dendritic cells, and macrophages. Acute rejection has been reported in 56-75% of patients, with small bowel transplant limiting the overall survival to only one-third of recipients.

questions.text: The structure marked with the asterisk in the electron micrograph indicates? (AIIMS 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Secretory vesicles

 

Explanation:

 

Presynaptic secretory vesicles are indicated by the asterisk in the electron micrograph. The structure with the arrowhead represents postsynaptic density.

 

Neurons produce secretory vesicles, which are involved in electrochemical signalling in the brain and neuromuscular junctions.

 

Synapse - electron microscopy

 

 

On electron microscopy:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mitochondria- On an electron microscope, mitochondria appear as round or elliptical bodies 0.5-2.0 micron long, with an outer and inner mitochondrial membrane, cristae, and mitochondrial matrix.

 

 

Option B.  Golgi bodies (or Golgi apparatus) appear as stacks of flattened membranous cisternae surrounded by clusters of vesicles.

 

 

Option D. Ribosomes may be attached to the membrane of the rough endoplasmic reticulum (as shown in the image below), or else, they may exist as monosomes or as a chain of granular structures called polyribosomes associated with mRNA

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Secretory vesicles are essential for neurotransmission at synapses, and play the critical role in neuronal communication.

choices.text: USG Doppler of right upper limb

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a smoking history of 36 pack years presents with numbness and weakness of the right hand and arm and tingling in the fingers. There is associated drooping of the right eye with miosis. What is the IOC for the patient? (AIIMS 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. MRI

 

Explanation:

 

  • The clinical presentation is pointing towards a diagnosis of right Pancoast or superior sulcus tumor involving the brachial plexus and sympathetic plexus.
  • Radiographic findings include an apical mass or unilateral or asymmetrical apical pleural thickening (“apical cap”).
  • Asymmetry in the thickness of an apical cap exceeding 5 mm is considered suggestive.
  • MRI is more accurate than CT in diagnosing brachial plexus and sympathetic plexus involvement, and define the relationship of the tumor to great vessels and the brachial plexus.

 

Regional spread can cause:

 

  • Tracheal obstruction

  • Esophageal compression with dysphagia

  • Recurrent laryngeal paralysis with hoarseness

  • Phrenic nerve palsy with the elevation of the hemidiaphragm and dyspnea

  • Sympathetic nerve paralysis with Horner's syndrome (enophthalmos, ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chest X-ray: While helpful for initial evaluation, it lacks the detail required to assess soft tissue involvement and the exact extent of the tumor.

 

Option B. USG Doppler of right upper limb: Useful for vascular assessment but not suitable for visualizing intrathoracic tumors or their impact on neural structures.

 

Option C. HRCT: High-resolution CT can identify the presence of an apical mass but does not provide as detailed visualization of soft tissue and neurovascular involvement as MRI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of suspected Pancoast tumor, MRI is preferred over other imaging modalities for its superior ability to delineate the extent of tumor involvement with the brachial plexus and sympathetic plexus, critical for accurate diagnosis and treatment planning.

questions.text: The following image of a FAST scan in a trauma patient suggests: (AIIMS 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Positive FAST

 

Explanation:

 

The ultrasound image shows an anechoic area (appearing dark on ultrasound), which is fluid between the liver and kidney. This finding is indicative of a hemoperitoneum, suggesting that the FAST (Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma) scan is positive. A positive FAST scan in this context typically points to the presence of free fluid in the abdomen, which in trauma settings, is usually due to bleeding, confirming a hemoperitoneum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Negative FAST: This would imply no visible free fluid; the image, however, shows clear evidence of fluid.

 

Option C. Equivocal FAST: This term would be used if the findings were unclear or uncertain, which is not the case here as the fluid is distinctly visible.

 

Option D. Pneumoperitoneum: This condition involves the presence of free air in the abdominal cavity and would present differently on an ultrasound, typically as increased echogenicity reflecting off the free air; this is not visible in the provided image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anechoic fluid between liver and kidney is suggestive of hemoperitoneum-FAST positive

 

eFAST: Extended Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma

 

Focus:

 

  • Hemoperitoneum (free fluid in abdomen)
  • Pericardial effusion
  • Pneumothorax
  • Hemothorax

questions.text: What to be done next? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Bone biopsy

 

  • The given X-ray image shows a bone tumor which needs to be diagnosed.
  • The image shows a well-defined, lytic lesion (a darker area indicating bone destruction) in the distal femur, specifically in the medial femoral condyle. 
  • The lesion appears somewhat expansile and has a narrow zone of transition, suggesting a benign or low-grade aggressive lesion rather than a highly aggressive malignant tumor. 
  • There's no clear periosteal reaction or soft tissue mass immediately evident.
  • This appearance is highly suggestive of a Giant Cell Tumor (GCT), given its typical location (epiphyseal/metaphyseal region of long bones), lytic nature, and often eccentric appearance. 
  • Other possibilities might include an aneurysmal bone cyst or a chondroblastoma, but GCT is a strong consideration.
  • To reach the correct and final diagnosis, a bone biopsy test must be done. 
  • Bone biopsy is the most appropriate "next step" to definitively diagnose the nature of the lesion before proceeding with a potentially complex surgical intervention.
  • Without a biopsy, one cannot be absolutely certain of the benign or malignant nature, or the specific type of tumor.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Extended curettage with allograft. Curettage involves scraping out the tumor. "Extended" curettage aims to remove as much of the tumor as possible while preserving the bone. After removal, the resulting cavity often needs to be filled to maintain structural integrity. An allograft is one option for filling. This is a common treatment for GCTs, especially those that are not highly aggressive or are in a location where wide excision would lead to significant functional impairment. Extended curettage remains the preferred treatment option for Grade I and II GCT due to least postoperative morbidity, cost-effectiveness, and surgical convenience. The risk of recurrence is high after curettage alone,and therefore adjuvants such as cryosurgery, cement, phenol or a combination of these are recommended. 

 

Option C. Curettage. Curettage alone might be insufficient for a lesion like a GCT due to its tendency for local recurrence. Compared with resection, curettage is associated with a higher rate of local recurrence; however, curettage often allows for a better functional result. Curettage can be extended by the use of adjuvants, such as liquid nitrogen, phenol, polymethylmethacrylate (PMMA), or thermal cautery to extend destruction of tumor cells. Bone cavities have been reinforced with autologous bone grafts, allograft, PMMA bone cement, demineralized bone matrix and bone graft substitutes. These fillers augment final bone strength, reduce the risk of local recurrence (esp. giant cell tumors) and fill the empty cavities. 

 

Educational Objective:

  • To reach the correct and final diagnosis, a bone biopsy test must be done. 
  • The management will follow the result of the bone biopsy. 
  • If the question implies "what is the definitive treatment generally indicated for a lesion with this appearance (strongly suggesting GCT)," then options A or D would be relevant. Giant Cell Tumors are known for local recurrence after simple curettage, which is why extended curettage (with or without adjuvant therapy) is the preferred surgical treatment.

questions.text: A patient presents with a 5 cm renal calculus causing severe flank pain. It is detected as a staghorn calculus. What is the best management? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy

 

PCNL is the preferred treatment for large and complex kidney stones, especially Staghorn calculi. It involves making a small incision in the patient's back to access the kidney directly. A nephroscope is then used to remove or break up the stone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ESWL (Extracorporeal Shock Wave Lithotripsy): ESWL is a non-invasive procedure that uses shock waves to break up kidney stones into smaller pieces, making them easier to pass. While ESWL is effective for smaller kidney stones, it may not be as successful for very large (> 2 cm) and complex Staghorn calculi.

 

Option C. Ureteroscopic removal: Ureteroscopy is a procedure that involves inserting a thin, flexible tube (ureteroscope) through the urethra and bladder to reach the stone in the ureter or renal pelvis. While it can be effective for ureteric stones, it may not be the best choice for Staghorn calculi, especially those larger than 4 cm.

 

Option D. Hydrotherapy: This can be tried for stones up to 5 mm in size. Larger stones would get obstructed in ureter.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy (PCNL) is a minimally invasive surgical procedure used to remove large kidney stones. The following are some of the indications for PCNL:

 

  1. Large or complex kidney stones (> 2 cm) or hard stones (Cysteine) that cannot be treated with other minimally invasive procedures such as shock wave lithotripsy (SWL) or ureteroscopy.
  2. Staghorn calculi (large branching stones) that occupy a significant portion of the kidney.
  3. Stones that are associated with renal obstruction or infection.

choices.text: GI manifestations occurs at a lower radiation dose than bone marrow depression
Bone marrow suppression appear at doses greater than 1 Gy
Bone marrow suppression occurs earlier than neurovascular effects
GI manifestations occur at a lower radiation dose than neurovascular effects

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding acute radiation syndrome? (AIIMS 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. GI manifestations occurs at a lower radiation dose than bone marrow depression

 

The statement that gastrointestinal (GI) manifestations occur at a lower radiation dose than bone marrow depression is false. In acute radiation syndrome (ARS), the threshold radiation dose for GI syndrome (8-12 Gy) is higher than that for hematopoietic syndrome, which involves bone marrow suppression (2-8 Gy). Therefore, bone marrow suppression occurs at lower doses compared to GI manifestations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bone marrow suppression appears at doses greater than 1 Gy: This statement is true as bone marrow suppression typically begins to appear at doses around 2 Gy, which is greater than 1 Gy.

 

Option C. Bone marrow suppression occurs earlier than neurovascular effects: This is true as bone marrow suppression from radiation occurs at lower doses and thus earlier than neurovascular effects, which occur at the highest dose thresholds (12-100 Gy).

 

Option D. GI manifestations occur at a lower radiation dose than neurovascular effects: This is true, as GI manifestations appear at a dose range of 8-12 Gy, which is lower than the dose range for neurovascular effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute Radiation Syndrome (ARS)

 

  • Occurs with accidental exposure of very high dose radiation
  • Result of nuclear accidents

questions.text: 50yr old male presenting with diffuse back pain; Cervical spine Xray shown. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. DISH

 

Explanation:

 

The age more than 50 yrs. and diffuse flowing ossification with no joint fusion and normal iv-disc space favors a diagnosis of DISH.

 

Diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis (DISH), also known as Forestier disease, is a common condition characterized by bony proliferation of the spine affecting elderly individuals. On imaging, it is typically characterized by the flowing ossification of the anterior longitudinal ligament involving the thoracic spine.

 

There is no involvement of the sacroiliac synovial joints.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ankylosing spondylitis: This condition would typically present with a "bamboo spine" appearance, resulting from fusion across the intervertebral disc spaces and sacroiliac joints, which is not evident in this X-ray.

 

Option C. Klippel-Feil syndrome: This syndrome involves congenital fusion of any two of the cervical vertebrae, which does not match the findings in this X-ray.

 

Option D. Sprengel deformity: This refers to an abnormally high scapula, a condition unrelated to the spinal changes observed in the X-ray.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DISH or Forestier's disease is recognized radiologically by its classic flowing ossification along the spine's anterior longitudinal ligament, sparing joint spaces and disc heights, often seen in individuals older than 50 years without signs of sacroiliac joint involvement.

 

DISH VS   Ankylosing spondylitis

choices.text: Tidal volume - 12 ml/kg of actual BW

questions.text: A patient of blunt chest trauma has been intubated and started on mechanical ventilation. Which of the following is not correct about the initial setting? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tidal volume – 12 ml/kg of actual BW 

 

  • Incorrect Setting: The generally recommended starting tidal volume for many patients, especially those at risk for or with established acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), is closer to 6 ml/kg of ideal body weight. Using 12 ml/kg of actual body weight can potentially lead to lung injury, especially in patients with pre-existing lung pathology or those who are at risk, such as trauma patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Respiratory rate - 12 Breaths/min: This is a typical starting point for the respiratory rate (RR) in many mechanically ventilated adults. The RR can be adjusted based on the patient's metabolic needs, acid-base balance, and CO2 levels.

 

Option B. PEEP - 5 cm H2O: Positive End-Expiratory Pressure (PEEP) helps keep alveoli open at the end of expiration, improving oxygenation and potentially preventing alveolar collapse. A starting PEEP of 5 cm H2O is a common initial setting in many ventilated patients, and it can be titrated based on oxygenation needs and potential hemodynamic effects.

 

Option C. FiO2 - 100%: Fraction of Inspired Oxygen (FiO2) refers to the concentration of oxygen in the gas mixture. Starting with a high FiO2, like 100%, ensures that the patient is receiving the maximum amount of oxygen. However, it's important to titrate this down as quickly as clinically feasible to avoid potential oxygen toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a patient started on mechanical ventilation, ideal ventilatory settings include a tidal volume of 4-6 ml/kg of ideal body weight, a respiratory rate of 12-18 breaths/min, an initial FiO2 of 100% titrated down to maintain SpO2 > 95%, and a starting PEEP of 5 cm H2O. Using a tidal volume of 12 ml/kg of actual body weight is incorrect and can lead to lung injury.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 2660

questions.text: Dicoumarol inhibits the action of vitamin K by? (AIIMS 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Competitive inhibition

 

Vitamin K Dependent Carboxylase is microsomal enzyme. It requires oxygen, CO2, NADPH and reduced vitamin K. In this process, the vitamin passes through a cycle. This process is competitively inhibited by warfarin and dicoumarol.

 

 

Vitamin K cycle

 

Dicoumarol - Structural analog inhibits vitamin K reductase

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Suicide inhibition:

  • Definition: The inhibitor binds irreversibly to the enzyme, inactivating it permanently.
  • Relevance: Dicoumarol does not irreversibly inactivate vitamin K reductase.

 

Option C. Noncompetitive inhibition:

  • Definition: The inhibitor binds to a different site on the enzyme, not the active site, altering the enzyme's activity.
  • Relevance: Dicoumarol competes at the active site, not at a different site.

 

Option D. Uncompetitive inhibition:

  • Definition: The inhibitor binds only to the enzyme-substrate complex, preventing the reaction from proceeding.
  • Relevance: Dicoumarol binds to the enzyme regardless of the presence of the substrate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dicoumarol inhibits the action of vitamin K by competitively inhibiting vitamin K reductase, preventing the regeneration of active vitamin K necessary for blood clotting.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought to the OPD with a parietal swelling present since birth. An X-ray was ordered and is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Cephalhematoma

 

Cephalohematomas are traumatic subperiosteal hematoma of the skull that are usually caused by birth injury. They are bound between the periosteum and cranium, and therefore cannot cross sutures. Being bound by a suture line distinguishes them from subgaleal hematoma, which can cross sutures.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Subgaleal hematoma: This hematoma is located beneath the scalp's aponeurotic layer and can spread widely over the skull, which is not confined by suture lines. Therefore, it is less likely to present as a localized swelling.
