Option C. Encephalocele: This is a neural tube defect characterized by the herniation of brain tissue through a defect in the skull. It is usually more severe and associated with neurological deficits.

 

Option D. Caput Succedaneum: This refers to swelling of the soft tissues of the scalp, which develops as the baby travels through the birth canal. This swelling can cross suture lines and typically resolves without intervention within the first few days of life.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cephalhematoma is a localized hematoma under the periosteum of the skull bone in newborns, confined by suture lines and typically associated with birth trauma.

questions.text: A patient presented with abdominal pain and sterile pyuria, and the x-ray showed the following features. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Putty kidney

 

Given patient with abdominal pain and sterile pyuria along with the given x-ray points to a diagnosis of a putty kidney.

 

GENITOURINARY TB

 

C/F - Increased frequency of urine

Urine Analysis - Sterile pyuria

Most Sensitive Investigation - IVP

Sign - Moth eaten calyces (irregularity of calyces d/t inflammation caused by TB bacillus)

Bladder - Thimble bladder (low volume bladder because of persistent inflammation)

END STAGE: Putty kidney [lobar calcification of kidney]

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nephrocalcinosis:  Calcium deposits in the kidney tissue itself due to any disorder that leads to high levels of calcium in the blood or urine

 

 

Option C. Staghorn calculi: usually develop due to prolonged urinary tract infections caused by urease-producing bacteria, such as Proteus, Klebsiella, and Pseudomonas species. Commonly composed of struvite.

 

 

Option D. Psoas calcification: This refers to calcification within the psoas muscle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Putty kidney is an advanced renal pathology often resulting from chronic infections such as tuberculosis, leading to extensive calcification and renal dysfunction. This condition is distinguishable on imaging by its irregular, extensive calcifications throughout the kidney, associated with clinical symptoms like abdominal pain and sterile pyuria.

choices.text: Apical segment of Right lower lobe consolidation
Posterior segment of right lower lobe consolidation

questions.text: A patient presents in OPD with a history of fever and cough for 5 days. On auscultation, crepts were heard on right side. Chest X-ray is given below. Mark the correct finding in this case? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Right middle lobe consolidation

 

Patient presenting with a history of fever and cough for 5 days suggests diagnosis pneumonia. The chest X-ray showing opacities with obscuration of the right cardiac border is suggestive of right middle lobe consolidation.

 

Right middle lobe pathology causes the obscuration of right cardiac border. In addition, the lateral view shows the opacity overlying the heart. In case of lower lobe opacities, the opacity overlays the spine.

 

 

The left image is a normal chest radiograph with the red line indicating the silhouette of the right heart border and right middle lobe.

 

The right image shows the same red line delineating where the silhouette should be, but is lost due to consolidation in the right middle lobe.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Right middle lobe consolidation is suggested by the obscuration of the right heart border and the specific location of opacity on the chest X-ray, aligned with the patient's clinical presentation of respiratory symptoms. This finding is crucial for diagnosing the specific location of pneumonia, guiding appropriate treatment.

questions.text: A defect in which of the following forms the structure marked below as A? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Fascia transversalis

 

Marked structure is the deep inguinal ring, formed by a defect in fascia transversalis.

 

The deep inguinal ring is an opening in the transversalis fascia present 1 cm above the inguinal ligament, midway between the anterior superior iliac spine and the pubic symphysis.

 

An indirect inguinal hernia arises through the deep inguinal ring, lateral to the inferior epigastric vessel.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Internal Oblique:  The internal oblique muscle is one of the three major muscles of the lateral abdominal wall. It lies just deep to the external oblique and superficial to the transversus abdominis.

 

  • Origin and Insertion: It originates from the lumbar fascia, anterior two-thirds of the iliac crest, and lateral half of the inguinal ligament. It inserts into the lower ribs, linea alba, and the pubic bone.
  • Innervation: It is innervated by the lower six thoracoabdominal nerves and the first lumbar nerve.

 

Option B. External Oblique: The external oblique is the most superficial of the three flat muscles of the lateral abdominal wall.

 

  • Origin and Insertion: It originates from the outer surfaces of the 5th to 12th ribs and inserts into the linea alba, pubic tubercle, and anterior half of the iliac crest.
  • Innervation: Like the internal oblique, it's innervated by the lower six thoracoabdominal nerves and the first lumbar nerve.

 

Option C. Parietal Peritoneum: The parietal peritoneum is the outer layer of the peritoneum that lines the internal surface of the abdominal wall.

 

  • Composition: It consists of a single layer of squamous epithelial cells (mesothelium) and its underlying connective tissue.
  • Innervation: The parietal peritoneum overlying the anterior abdominal wall is primarily innervated by the lower six thoracoabdominal nerves and the first lumbar nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fascia Transversalis: The fascia transversalis is a thin aponeurotic membrane which lies between the inner surface of the transversus abdominis muscle and the parietal peritoneum. It covers the entire inner surface of the abdominal wall and is continuous with the iliac and pelvic fasciae.

 

Hernias that penetrate the fascia transversalis in the groin region are called direct inguinal hernias.

questions.text: A 5-year-old male child presented with fever, fatigue and left ventricular dysfunction. He underwent a cardiac biopsy (image shown). Which of the following is the likely diagnosis in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lymphocytic myocarditis

 

The clinical presentation of fever, fatigue, and left ventricular dysfunction in a young child, along with the histopathological image from the cardiac biopsy, is suggestive of lymphocytic myocarditis.

 

Lymphocytic Myocarditis:

 

  • Pathology: Characterized by interstitial inflammation with a predominance of lymphocytes. The image provided shows myocardial fibers with an interstitial infiltrate primarily composed of lymphocytes. Associated myocyte necrosis
  • Etiology: Commonly caused by viral infections such as coxsackievirus, adenovirus, and parvovirus B19.
  • Clinical Features: Patients may present with signs and symptoms of heart failure, arrhythmias, and systemic symptoms like fever and fatigue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute rheumatic fever: Typically shows Aschoff bodies with Anitschkow cells on biopsy, which are not present in the provided image.

 

Option C. Chagas disease: Caused by Trypanosoma cruzi, characterized by amastigotes in myocardial cells, often with mixed inflammatory infiltrate, not just lymphocytes.

 

Option D. Pyogenic myocarditis: Characterized by the presence of neutrophils, indicating bacterial infection, which is not seen in the provided image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lymphocytic myocarditis is indicated by the presence of lymphocytic infiltration in the myocardium and is commonly associated with viral infections. The clinical presentation includes heart failure symptoms, fever, and fatigue.

 

 

Lymphocytic myocarditis

 

 

Hypersensitivity myocarditis

 

 

Giant cell myocarditis

 

 

Myocarditis of Chagas disease (arrow showing trypanosomes)

questions.text: Identify the imaging modality given below. (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. PET CT

 

The above imaging modality is a PET CT scan.

 

  • PET scan: Positron emission tomography
  • 18-FDG: 18F is combined with deoxy glucose (ligand)
  • To look for malignant cells
  • Functional metabolism

 

Warburg Effect: Malignant cells → anaerobic glycolysis

 

 

  • Concept: Coincidence – Annihilation reaction
  • Prerequisite before performing PET scan: Blood glucose measurement

 

Other Options:

 

Option. A. Cerebral blood flow scan: Typically involves methods like SPECT or perfusion MRI to measure blood flow in the brain.

 

 

Option. C. Sestamibi scan: Generally used for myocardial perfusion imaging or parathyroid imaging, involving a different radiotracer.

 

 

Option. D. Full body MDCT (Multi-detector computed tomography): Provides high-resolution anatomical information across the whole body.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A PET CT scan is crucial for the integrated assessment of anatomical and metabolic information, particularly useful in oncology for identifying and tracking the behavior of tumors based on their glucose metabolism, as visualized through radiotracer uptake.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the casualty following a road traffic accident. On examination, the patient is conscious, BP is 90/60 mm Hg, respiratory rate is 40 breaths per minute, and pulse rate is 120 bpm. The X-ray is shown below. What is the next best step in management? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Needle thoracostomy

 

The clinical scenario of an unstable patient and the given X-ray findings, which showing hyperlucent right hemithorax with contralateral mediastinal shift is suggestive of a tension pneumothorax. Inserting a wide-bore needle in the 5th ICS anterior to the midaxillary line followed by a chest tube in the triangle of safety is the best course of action for the management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. A. Pericardiocentesis: This is performed in cases of cardiac tamponade (when presents with beck’s triad), where there is fluid accumulation in the pericardial sac, not applicable here as the X-ray does not suggest this condition.

 

Option. B. Thoracotomy: Indicated for more complex chest injuries or when less invasive procedures fail to resolve the issue. It's a more invasive approach typically reserved for critical cases not resolved by needle thoracostomy or chest tube insertion.

 

Option. D. Chest tube insertion: While ultimately necessary for ongoing management and air evacuation, initial needle thoracostomy is critical to quickly relieve the pressure due to its speed and efficacy in an emergency setting. Chemical pleurodesis, which involves inhaling talc into the chest cavity, is used to achieve pleural adhesion.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presents to the paediatrician with a history of recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs). Upon further investigation, a micturating cystourethrogram is performed and which is shown below. The boy is currently asymptomatic and has no history of renal or bladder abnormalities. What could be the cause of the symptoms? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vesicoureteral reflux

 

  • In above case scenario recurrent urinary tract infections and the micturating cystourethrogram showing dilated ureters points towards the diagnosis of vesicoureteral reflux (VUR).
  • Vesicoureteral reflux is a condition where urine flows retrogradely from the bladder back into the ureters and possibly up to the kidneys.
  • VUR is a common cause of recurrent UTIs in children, especially when no other anatomical abnormalities are identified.
  •  The presented imaging findings and clinical history are consistent with VUR.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urinary bladder diverticulum: This refers to an outpouching of the bladder wall. It can be congenital or acquired, and these outpouchings can retain urine and be sites of recurrent infections. While bladder diverticula can cause UTIs, the described imaging findings (a dilated ureter) do not align with this diagnosis.

 

 

Option C. Urinary bladder hernia: This is a very rare condition where a portion of the urinary bladder herniates into the surrounding tissue or space. It is not typically associated with the findings described in the scenario.

 

Option D. Varicocele : A varicocele refers to an enlargement of the veins within the scrotum. It is not related to the imaging findings described in the scenario or the symptoms of recurrent UTIs in the patient.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) is a common cause of recurrent urinary tract infections in children. The condition is characterized by the retrograde flow of urine from the bladder into the ureters and potentially up to the kidneys. Imaging findings showing dilated ureters on a micturating cystourethrogram are indicative of VUR.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with spinal TB; he has a swelling in the left groin with limb attitude is in flexion. Identify what caused it? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical scenario of a patient with Pott spine having persistent hip flexion with a history of spinal tuberculosis is suggestive of psoas abscess involving the psoas muscle, marked A in the given coronal CT image.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with spinal TB, a psoas abscess is a significant complication that can lead to symptoms such as groin swelling and changes in limb posture due to its location and the effect of the abscess on the surrounding structures, particularly the psoas muscle. Prompt recognition and treatment are crucial to manage symptoms and prevent further complications.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man weighing 70 kg had a sodium level of 120 mEq, calculate sodium deficit? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 840 mEq

 

Explanation

 

The sodium deficit in the given scenario is 840 mEq.

 

Formula for calculating sodium deficit = 0.6 × body weight x (target plasma sodium concentration - starting plasma sodium concentration).

 

Substituting values as per the question,

 

Sodium deficit = 0.6 x 70 × (140 - 120) = 840 mEq.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Correcting sodium levels must be done cautiously, especially in cases of hyponatremia, to prevent complications like osmotic demyelination syndrome. Rapid changes in serum sodium can be dangerous, and adjustments should generally be made slowly, according to specific clinical guidelines.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male who engaged in unprotected sexual intercourse develops urethral discharge one week later as shown in the given image below. What is the most likely causative organism for this condition? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neisseria gonorrhea

 

The given image shows purulent urethral discharge that developed one week after unprotected sexual intercourse is suggestive of acute urethritis. The most likely causative organism for acute urethritis in males is Neisseria gonorrhea.

 

Purulent urethral discharge can be seen in gonorrhea caused by Neisseria gonorrhea or lymphogranuloma venerum caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

 

Gonorrhea:

 

Gonorrhea is a disease acquired by sexual contact. The first step in infection is the infection of gonococci to the urethra or other mucosal surfaces. Pilli is involved in this adhesion. The cocci penetrate the intracellular spaces and reach subepithelial tissue by the third day of infection. The incubation period is 2-8 days. The major symptoms include urethral discharge and dysuria, usually without urinary frequency or urgency. The specific symptoms seen in males and females are as follows:

 

In males:

 

  • ﻿﻿The disease starts as acute urethritis. This infection may extend along the urethra to involve the prostate, seminal vesicles, and epididymis.
  • ﻿﻿Chronic urethritis may lead to stricture formation.
  • ﻿﻿The infection may spread to the periurethral tissues causing abscesses and multiple discharging sinuses (watercan perineum).

 

In females:

 

  • ﻿﻿The initial infection involves the cervix uteri and urethra which may extend to Bartholin glands, endometrium, and fallopian tubes.
  • ﻿﻿The vaginal mucosa is not usually affected in adults because the stratified squamous epithelium is resistant to infection by the cocci, and also because of the acidic pH of vaginal secretions.
  • ﻿﻿Pelvic inflammatory disease and salpingitis may lead to sterility.
  • ﻿﻿Rarely peritonitis may develop with perihepatic inflammation (Fitz Hugh Curtis syndrome)

 

Lab diagnosis:

 

The discharge is collected and subjected to Gram's stain which reveals gram-negative intracellular diplococci within phagocytes. Stuart's transport medium is used. Cultures can be obtained from chocolate agar or Mueller-Hinton agar. Specifically, Thayer-Martin agar is used to isolate Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

 

Treatment: Ceftriaxone (250mg, IM) single-dose + azithromycin 1 g PO, single-dose or doxycycline 100 mg PO BD for 7 days

 

The image below shows the Gram-stain of a urethral exudate showing typical intracellular gram-negative diplococci and pleomorphic extracellular gram-negative organisms

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Ureaplasma urealyticum is the second most common cause of non-gonococcal urethritis next to chlamydia. That is why the initial etiological agent under suspicion always remains gonorrhea.

 

Option C. Herpes Simplex will be associated with vesicular lesions.

 

Option D. Trichomonas vaginalis generally presents with a frothy discharge

 

Educational Objective

 

Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a significant cause of sexually transmitted infections, manifesting as acute urethritis with purulent discharge in males. Prompt diagnosis and treatment with appropriate antibiotics, such as a combination of ceftriaxone and azithromycin, are crucial to prevent complications and limit the spread of this highly contagious infection.

 

Non-gonococcal urethritis is caused by:

 

  • ﻿﻿Chlamydia trachomatis
  • ﻿﻿Ureaplasma urealyticum
  • ﻿﻿Mycoplasma genitalium
  • ﻿﻿Trichomonas vaginalis
  • ﻿﻿Herpes simplex virus (rare)
  • ﻿﻿Adenovirus
  • ﻿﻿Haemophilus vaginalis
  • ﻿﻿Mycoplasma genitalium

questions.text: A 10-year-old child was operated for a tumour in the lower end of femur. The gross specimen of the resected tumour is shown below. What is the diagnosis? (INCET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteosarcoma

 

OSTEOSARCOMA

 

  • The matrix forming the tumor is the cause of calcification.
  • It is the second most common primary malignancy of bone behind multiple myeloma.
  • The classic form of osteosarcoma is typically seen in patients in their second or third decade, with a peak in the adolescent growth spurt.
  • It occurs more frequently in males than in females and is found in the metaphyseal areas of long bones, with 50% of lesions about the knee joint.
  • The distal femur is the most common site, followed by the proximal tibia and then the proximal humerus.
  • Characteristic histological feature is malignant cells with osteoid formation. This osteoid matrix presents as calcification.
  • Osteosarcoma is the most common radiation-induced sarcoma.
  • Clinical features:
    • Almost all patients report progressive pain. Night pain may be an important clue to the true diagnosis, seen in 25% of patients
       
  • Radiological Features:
    • Permeated lytic destruction of metaphyseal bone, with eventual cortical breakthrough into the subperiosteal space and subsequent formation of a Codman triangle at the diaphyseal end of the tumor.

 

 

Codman’s triangle

 

  • As the tumor continues to push its way into the extracortical soft tissue, a typical sunburst pattern of neoplastic bone may be seen outside the involved bone.

 

 

  • MRI is the best test to measure the extent of the tumor within the bone and in the soft tissue and to determine the relationship of the tumor to nearby anatomical structures.
  • A bone scan should be obtained to look for skeletal metastases, and radiographs and CT scans of the chest should be done to search for pulmonary metastases; the lungs are the most common sites of metastases.
  • CT scan may be helpful in differentiating osteosarcoma from myositis ossificans or an osteochondroma. The ossification in myositis ossificans is more mature at the periphery of the lesion, whereas the center of osteosarcoma is more heavily ossified.
  • Treatment:
    • It is highly radio-resistant tumor and ideally, treated by chemotherapy followed by limb salvage surgery/amputation followed by chemotherapy.
    • With the combination of chemotherapy and surgical treatment, the prognosis for 5-year survival is 70-80%.
    • The drugs commonly used today include high-dose methotrexate, doxorubicin, cisplatin, and ifosfamide.
    • In osteosarcoma of the extremities, limb-sparing surgery with wide resection of the tumor is the standard approach.
    • Amputation is reserved for the exceptional or recurrent case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chondrosarcoma. It occurs over a broad age range, with peaks between 40 and 60 years for primary chondrosarcoma and between 25 and 45 years for secondary chondrosarcoma. Most common in Proximal location like pelvis (most common site), proximal femur, and proximal humerus. Most common malignant tumor of bone in hand (although rarely occur). Secondary chondrosarcomas arise at the site of a pre-existing benign cartilage lesion like in case of multiple enchondromas and multiple hereditary exostoses. Chondrosarcoma can produce hyperglycemia in 85% cases. Metastasis from Chondrosarcoma most commonly goes to lungs (hematogenous). The radiographic appearance is similar to enchondroma, it is a lesion arising in the medullary cavity with irregular matrix calcification. The pattern of Calcification is described as “Punctate”, “popcorn”, or “comma-shaped”. It has a more aggressive appearance with Bone destruction, cortical erosions, periosteal reaction, and rarely a soft-tissue mass. Treatment is by Wide local excision/Radical excision.

 

 

Option C. GCT. They typically occur in patients 20-40 years old, and there is a slight female predominance. The most common location for this tumor is the distal femur, followed closely by the proximal tibia. Tumor of lower end radius is GCT till proved otherwise. GCT has egg shell crackling on palpation. Although these tumors typically are benign, pulmonary metastases occur in approximately 3% of patients. Malignant giant cell tumors represent less than 5% of total GCT. Radiographic findings often are diagnostic. The lesions are eccentrically located in the epiphyses of long bones and usually about the subchondral bone with soap bubble appearance. Microscopically, giant cell tumors are composed of many multinucleated giant cells (typically 40-60 nuclei per cell) in a sea of mononuclear stromal cells (malignant cells). Curettage and stripping of the cavity is the treatment of choice.

 

 

Option D. Chondroblastoma. Chondroblastoma is a rare type of benign tumor that grows at the ends of the long bones, close to the joints. Most often, the tumors develop at the ends of the femur, tibia, or humerus. They typically occur in children and young adults, and are more common in males. Although chondroblastomas are not cancerous, they can continue to grow if left untreated. A growing tumor can destroy the surrounding bone, making it painful to move the nearby joint. The cause of chondroblastomas is not known. The tumors are thought to arise from the growth plates at the ends of the bones, near joints. Classic “chicken wire” calcification is seen. Epiphysis + calcification + upper end humerus = Chondroblastoma.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image in the question shows a cut section of osteosarcoma of the femur.
  • The destructive tumor arises from the metaphysis, with extensive involvement of the marrow cavity and extension into soft tissue.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient comes to the clinic with a history of rapidly enlarging swelling in her right breast for the last 15 days. During the physical examination, there was a local rise in temperature, and the lump was partially mobile over the chest wall. What could be the probable diagnosis for this patient? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inflammatory carcinoma

 

Inflammatory breast cancer (IBC) is a rare and aggressive form of breast cancer. It presents with rapid onset of swelling (edema), redness (erythema), and warmth due to its tendency to block the lymphatic vessels in the skin of the breast. This blockage leads to the classic "peau d'orange" appearance, resembling the skin of an orange. A local rise in temperature and rapid progression of symptoms (as in 15 days) can be consistent with inflammatory carcinoma. The tumor might be mobile initially, but as the disease progresses, it becomes fixed. Given the described symptoms and rapid onset, inflammatory carcinoma is a probable diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Giant fibroadenoma: Fibroadenomas are benign tumors composed of glandular and connective tissue. They are usually painless, mobile, and have a rubbery consistency. While they don't typically present with inflammation or a rapid onset of symptoms, giant fibroadenomas are larger than typical fibroadenomas (>5cm). They are seen in the 15 to 25 year old age group.

 

Option C. Phyllodes tumor: Phyllodes tumors are rare breast tumors that can be benign, borderline, or malignant. They can grow quickly and become quite large, and while they might be mobile, they do not typically present with inflammatory signs like warmth or redness.

 

Option D. Galactocele: A galactocele is a milk-filled cyst that can form in the breast. It typically presents in women who are lactating or have recently stopped lactating. While a galactocele can cause a lump in the breast, it doesn't cause inflammatory symptoms such as a local rise in temperature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the given scenario, the patient's rapid onset of disease and examination findings suggest inflammatory carcinoma of the breast, which is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer.
  • Inflammatory breast cancer typically presents with brawny induration, erythema with a raised edge, and edema (Peau d'orange appearance), along with a breast lump.
  • Skin biopsy is used to diagnose inflammatory breast cancer.
  • The treatment for inflammatory breast cancer includes combined-modality treatment, such as neoadjuvant chemotherapy, mastectomy, radiation therapy, hormonal therapy for ER-positive tumors, and Trastuzumab for HER-2-positive tumors.

questions.text: Identify the imaging modality given below? (INCET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) USG

 

Explanation:

 

The given image is suggestive of USG of the neck.

 

The thyroid gland, muscles, blood vessels, bony structures or cartilages, and nerves are all visible on a sonographic examination of the neck.

 

On USG, normal thyroid appears homogeneously hyperechoic with a uniform echotexture. Large blood vessels (the common carotid artery and, more laterally, the internal jugular vein) can be seen laterally to the thyroid.

 

USG is the radiological IOC to evaluate thyroid nodules.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fluoroscopy: Primarily used for real-time imaging of moving body structures using X-rays, which is not indicated by the type of static image and detail shown.

 

Option C. X-Ray: Typically shows denser tissues like bones and lacks the detailed soft tissue contrast visible in this ultrasound image.

 

Option D. MRI: Provides high-resolution images of internal structures using magnetic fields and radio waves, typically not showing the real-time flow or specific echogenic properties visible in ultrasound images.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ultrasound (USG) is the imaging modality of choice for evaluating the thyroid and other neck structures due to its ability to provide detailed images of soft tissue structures without exposure to ionizing radiation. It is particularly useful for assessing the thyroid gland, including the evaluation of nodules and vascular structures.

questions.text: What is the structure marked in the CT scan? (INCET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Anterior ethmoidal canal  

 

Explanation:

 

Anterior ethmoidal canal is noted by the marked arrows. The anterior ethmoidal canal can be recognized by the fact that it lies below the ethmoidal air cell roof. To prevent bleeding from this vessel during sinus procedures, it is crucial to recognize that the anterior ethmoidal artery runs via this canal. Maxillary sinus is noted in this view hence suggesting anterior plane.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. The posterior ethmoidal artery, vein, and nerve pass via the ethmoid bone’s posterior ethmoid canal or foramen. Due to the fact that this image is a coronal section taken at the level of the anterior ethmoidal cells, it cannot be seen.

 

Option C. The optic nerve can be identified as an oval intraorbital structure in the coronal sections.

 

Option D. The cribriform plate is a sieve-like structure between the nasal cavity and the anterior cranial fossa. It is part of the ethmoid bone and as it is pierced by the olfactory nerve fibers. Crista Galli is also a part of ethmoid bone that projects superiorly from the cribriform plate. It provides attachment for the falx cerebri.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anterior ethmoidal canal is critical to identify during sinus procedures to avoid complications such as bleeding from the anterior ethmoidal artery. It is located below the roof of the ethmoidal air cells and anterior to the posterior ethmoidal canal.
